linkTarget.anchoringText: The Yu. Korchagin field is located in the Russian sector of the Caspian sea (fig. 1). Distance to the nearest shore (delta of the Volga river) is 120 km. Nearest seaports are located in the city of Astrakhan (175 km) and in Makhachkala, Kizlyar and Derbent. The Yu. Korchagin field is the first field put into operation in the Caspian sea. It was discovered in 2000 by drilling of well No. 1-Shirotnaya, and put into production operation in 2010. Oil

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: The Russian sector in the North Caspian Sea. The Yu. Korchagin field

formatted-caption.caption-text: The Russian sector in the North Caspian Sea. The Yu. Korchagin field

linkTarget.anchoringText: The deposit is a thin oil rim clastic reservoir with an average thickness of 20 metres, bounded by a massive gas cap approximately 100 meters in height and an underlying active acquifer (fig.2). The Neocom formation's GOC and WOC is located at -1517 m and 1537 m respectively. Effective thickness of the oil rim has considerable gas and water-oil transition zones and is characterized with heterogeneity of filtration properties (table 1).

image-wrap.caption: Tracer systems are the rod shaped polymers. They are installed between screen filters and base pipe and housed by the rib wires, base pipe OD and ID of wire wrap.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Tracer systems are the rod shaped polymers. They are installed between screen filters and base pipe and housed by the rib wires, base pipe OD and ID of wire wrap.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Therefore, the tracer placement strategy was to position each tracer in separate completion interval with high permeability and stay approximately 5 m above the GOC. In addition, the blind zones adjacent to the monitored zones were also located in the interval with the similar reservoir properties. The final placement of the eight tracers along the horizontal producing interval is illustrated in figure 6 and figure 7 Fig..

image-wrap.caption: Tracer systems placement and "blind" zones in the pilot well. The highlighted circles indicate the intervals of the well nearest to the GOC

linkTarget.anchoringText: Being constructed in 2014, the well was started up in transient state in order to clear out the horizontal wellbore. After well clean up, some hydrodynamic surveys were performed with stable and transient states, and depending on it samples of the produced fluid were taken for the purpose of tracer detection. Before the startup, the pilot well was shut-in for 36 hours. The well was started up with 16.67 mm surface choke, and 88 samples were taken. Based on the data of well performance, during restart of the well (Fig. 8) and with account of the well downhole geometry, 42 samples of 8 oil tracers were collected for analysis (Fig.). The results of laboratory analysis are presented as calculated concentration of tracer in oil samples in Fig.10 and Fig.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Theoretical response dependency in the inflow interval. A higher flow rate (2Q) gives an initially higher and more rapidly declining tracer response than a section with lower production rate (Q) assuming all other parameters kept constant

formatted-caption.caption-text: Theoretical response dependency in the inflow interval. A higher flow rate (2Q) gives an initially higher and more rapidly declining tracer response than a section with lower production rate (Q) assuming all other parameters kept constant

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Collected (black triangles) and analyzed (red triangles) samples of oil tracers, green line is production rate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Collected (black triangles) and analyzed (red triangles) samples of oil tracers, green line is production rate

linkTarget.anchoringText: Being constructed in 2014, the well was started up in transient state in order to clear out the horizontal wellbore. After well clean up, some hydrodynamic surveys were performed with stable and transient states, and depending on it samples of the produced fluid were taken for the purpose of tracer detection. Before the startup, the pilot well was shut-in for 36 hours. The well was started up with 16.67 mm surface choke, and 88 samples were taken. Based on the data of well performance, during restart of the well (Fig. 8) and with account of the well downhole geometry, 42 samples of 8 oil tracers were collected for analysis (Fig.). The results of laboratory analysis are presented as calculated concentration of tracer in oil samples in Fig.10 and Fig..

During one-year period of well operation in constant steady state, recurrent studies with samples collection for laboratory analyses have been performed. In steady state the tracer discharge into the target fluid is constant. In theory, cumulative mass of released tracer should be constantly growing (dashed line in Fig. 12). Based on the tracer concentrations detected in samples and well performance, cumulative curve of tracer release is drawn for each tracer rod. Deviation of the cumulative tracer release curve from the theoretical line means that lingered fluid with tracer has been recovered (increase of tracer release) or that tracer rod has had less contact with target fluid (decrease of tracer release).

(1) High increase of tracer release in zone 7 happened during switching to minimum choke (7.94 mm), which shows that fluid with tracer has lingered in the wellbore when standard choke was used, and that this fluid with tracer has been flushed out due to increased inflow in zone 7 at low pressure drawdown. At the same time, tracer flushing-out from zones 1 and 2 is reduced when the minimum choke is used, (2) inflow from zones 1 and 2 resumes after switching to a larger choke (9.52 mm) (Fig. 13).

When switching to 9.52 mm choke, the inflow in the heel (zones 6, 7, 8) decreases. The inflow in the heel resumes when the choke is replaced with 11.91 mm one. (2) Increased production in zone 3 is registered with chokes 9.5…14.29 mm (Fig. 14).

When switching to standard 15.88 mm choke the production in zones 7 and 3 is decreased, balanced (optimal) production in zones with 15.88 mm choke, zone 5 is generally the least sensitive to the choke diameter, zone 7 is the most sensitive to it (Fig. 15).

The tracer responses demonstrate that initial stage of the transient flow state after the well startup is characterized by unstable bottom-hole pressure and show distorted tracer responses with multiple peaks, which in their turn may indicate the adjustment of ICDs to the working parameters (pressure balancing and gas inflow restriction) (Fig. 16). The splitting-up of the signal peaks may indicate that fluid is not static when the well is shut-in, i.e. some flow between the zones may take place.

Steady responses from all tracer systems have been detected, and it confirms that inflow takes place in all zones where tracer rods are installed. Single and multiple spikes of signals during the initial period after the well startup indicate high inflow of oil and gas mixture, further stabilization and smooth decrease of signals indicates that the inflow was restricted by AICDs. Relatively small amplitude and distorted form of signal from the tracer rod in zone 4 show that there was a significant inflow of gas or water. The results of quantitative assessment of the inflow profile are given in Fig. 17.
Fig. 18 gives comparative data on inflow profile during startup mode in December 2014 and January

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of inflow profile during well startup in January 2016 and December 2014

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of inflow profile during well startup in January 2016 and December 2014
